Napier’s prudish past: Bylaw fined people who wore swimming togs crossing road https://www.nzherald.co.nz/hawkes-bay-today/news/napiers-prudish-past-the-bylaw-that-fined-people-who-wore-swimming-togs-while-crossing-road/ KHYYP52GBJEGVJWGUVPJJFO7ZM/ https://www.nzherald.co.nz/hawkes-bay-today/news/napiers-prudish-past-the-bylaw-that-fined-people-who-wore-swimming-togs-while-crossing-road/ KHYYP52GBJEGVJWGUVPJJFO7ZM/ Michael FowlerOPINION: Napier had a prudish past - especially when it came to public bathing. Fri, 19 Jan 2024 17:00:00 +0000 A beach scene in January 1911 on Napier’s Marine Parade. The Municipal Baths can be seen in the background. Mixing bathing – as can be seen - was the envy of many in New Zealand at the time.
Photo / Collection of Hawke's Bay Museums Trust, Ruawharo Tā-ū-rangi, 3339
